headline: Ukrainian Red Borscht Soup
description: This borscht recipe makes a delicious version of the classic beet soup. Crumbled sausage makes it very hearty, or you can omit it for a vegetarian soup.

video.description: See how to make authentic beet soup from the Ukraine.
video.name: Ukrainian Red Borscht Soup

name: Ukrainian Red Borscht Soup
recipeIngredient: 3 medium baking potatoes, peeled and cubed
0.5 medium head cabbage, cored and shredded
8.75 cups water, divided, or as needed
1 teaspoon white sugar, or to taste
1 tablespoon chopped fresh parsley for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Crumble sausage into a skillet set over medium-high heat. Cook and stir until no longer pink. Remove from the heat and set aside.
Fill a large pot halfway with water (about 8 cups) and bring to a boil.
Add sausage to pot, cover pot, and return to a boil. Add beets and cook until they have lost their color. Add carrots and potatoes and simmer until tender, about 15 minutes.
Add cabbage and diced tomatoes to pot.
Heat oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add onion and cook until tender. Stir in tomato paste and remaining 3/4 cup water until well blended. Transfer to the pot.
Add garlic to the soup, cover, and turn off the heat. Let stand 5 minutes. Stir in sugar and season with salt and pepper.
Ladle into serving bowls. Garnish with sour cream and parsley.

review.reviewBody: I would describe it as goulash, but I am American and have no European culinary expertise. Doesn't have as much beet flavor as I expected but still good. I cooked the onion along with the carrots rather than separately in a skillet, and I cooked the cabbage until thoroughly done. It took me twice as long to prep and cook as the recipe indicates.

This was the first time I've had borscht and now I see why so many people love it. I can't believe how good it is. I followed this recipe exactly with the following exceptions. One, because the russet potatoes I had were on the small side, I used six of them instead of three. Two, instead of using 8 ounces of tomatoes, I used an entire 14.5 ounce can and I didn't drain it. I dumped the entire can into the pot, liquid and all. I don't think doing this changed the flavor of the borscht very much, if at all. Finally, instead of using 8 cups of water I used 4 cups of water, 2 cups of chicken broth and 2 cups of vegetable broth. I highly recommend not skipping the sour cream or the fresh parsley or dill. They add a great deal to the flavor. Also, the recipe says to add salt and pepper to taste. I used 1 teaspoon of salt and half a teaspoon of pepper and that worked well for me. I'm going to add this recipe to my list of keepers. This is one of the tastiest dishes I've ever had.

Very good. Made borscht one other time with a different recipe that was not as good as this. Used chicken bone broth instead of water and chicken sausage---it's what I had, would probably recommend going with the pork... my wife called it "peasant food" I gently reminded her that she married beneath her class üòÜ good soup though.

Great recipe! Made it because we picked up too many beets at the farmer's market. I used vegetable stock, which I prefer to the flavour of beef stock. Took it to Thanksgiving dinner - my in-laws are all very good cooks and they enjoyed it thoroughly (even tho we forgot the sour cream ;))
Delicious! I added more beets for fun (7 total). I shredded most of my veggies, but I plan to try small chunks next time.
My husband HATES beets and he loved it!
First time trying this soup very good my neighbors even liked it

My son and I made this for dinner last night. It was our first time ever having borscht and it was REALLY good! It takes quite a bit of prep but with the both of us working together, it came together nicely. We didn't have sour cream, so we used plain Greek yogurt to serve with it instead. Thinking of you, Ukraine!
Very good and different than most foods I‚Äôve had. Definitely make it!
Imprecise recipe. It‚Äôs really a pot a feu preparation but you couldn‚Äôt figure that out from the recipe. The ideas are good but cooks should stick with something where the amounts are spelled out.
Worth it.

All beet borscht soup recipes are delicious. Each adds the taste of the region from whence they originated. If you love beets you‚Äôll love the soup. My mom‚Äôs handed down to me is different than all those I reviewed at by this or that but the base is beets. Of course my moms is my favorite but I‚Äôll give each of the different recipes a try to see if there‚Äôs any tweaking I might do to my own. Enjoy all the creativity. Thank God for our differences otherwise we‚Äôd be bland and so would our recipes.
This was as close to my Grammas Borscht as I've had. I've never made it before, so I followed the recipe to a T (omitting the meat) and my first bite mixed with some sour cream was heaven! Well done.
Tasted amazing!
It is fabulous! Confident in sharing with friends. It is delicious!
I did not shred my veggies and did not add tomato paste. Used chicken stock. So wonderful and flavourful. Just great soup

Great soup. Made a gazpacho . I had cooked beets so added them as chunks after blending. Left out sugar, added lemon zest and dill. Greek yogurt for topping. Saut√©ed holy trinity. Created hot spot for paste to bring out a hearty flavor .
Great and easy recipe for first time borscht makers. Lots of preparations and as such something great to do with the family.

This is the best borscht ever. Thank you so much for this recipe. My local Russian restaurant in Dallas was my go-to when I craved borscht. They‚Äôll be disappointed to know that I‚Äôve found an even better option. Thank you

This is pretty good. My husband I love this (we met in a Russian history class in Graduate school - hee hee) and we have tried a variety of internet based recipes. Borscht is a peasant soup and it should be easy, so I do cheat and use 1 15 oz can of unsalted sliced beets. (I halved the recipe). I am really lazy about boiling and peeling and grating. I add one stick of celery for flavor and only add about one to two tbs of tomato paste. I add the parsley, brown sugar, salt and pepper about five minutes before finishing and let it summer a bit. Most importantly, in our limited experience, is to make it in the morning of the day you want to eat itand let it sit for a few hours. Get a hearty bread to eat it with. My husband has heart issues so the pork allows me to get away with about 1 tbs of salt for half a stock pot worth of soup.
Adding the sour cream really tops off this delicious winter staple.

I followed the advice of another reviewer and boiled my beets whole and shredded them, adding them about 5 mins before it finished cooking. This gave a beautiful dark red color. I also I didn't add the sugar. tasted wonderful.
Tasteless and watery. Should use broth, not water.
Followed recipe exactly except without cabbage. Turned out amazing!
Excellent soup! I make it often, sometimes using spicy Italian sausage.
Tastes so much like Babas I was very pleased! I used bok choy instead of cabbage and garbanzo beans instead of white beans and it couldn‚Äôt have turned out better!
Just perfect. Classic recipe, Great taste, my favorite.
Was good just not extra

after making it I would have to say this is definitely a regional variation... likely more Russian my great grandmother says. We swap the garlic for dill and use seared pork ribs to make the stock. We dont shred our veggies aside from cabbage as we may spend a week eating a large pot. we usually make about 4x this recipe.
Made this at work and got multiple compliments. I even got a ‚Äújust like my mama used to make back home‚Äù!
Very good as per recipe. Didn't change a thing.
Great recipe. Easy to make. Would add some dill.
Very tasty!

I made this for a dinner party of 8. Every bowl was emptied and everyone had seconds. So yummy. First time for all of us to eat borscht. I topped it with dill and sour cream because it said to do so in the recipe. So good!
Very good and I was born in Poland
I use daily butternut squash instead of potatoes. Gave it a sweeter twist.

BEST BORSCHT EVER! I have made many different beet soup recipes over the years. The addition of an acidic ingredient (tomato) still allowed the beets to shine but removed the heavy, sometimes too earthy taste common to borscht. I have never made borscht with meat before as this soup is generally a vegetarian dish served on December 24. The added sausage raised the notch even higher. My husband, who hates beets (and especially borscht) ate this soup. 'Nuff said.
I made this exactly as the recipe stated. It was fabulous! This is a definite make-again. There is nothing I would do differently.

One guest who was served this soup, indicated that she had been dreaming of a second bowl and hoped that we had leftovers; there is no higher praise for a cook than that. My wife wanted a second batch so we skipped hot pickled beets. Do not omit the sour cream; I remove sour cream from everything, but it adds something to this dish...

First off, thank you for sharing this recipe. I‚Äôve always wanted to try ‚Äúreal‚Äù Ukrainian borscht. I had cooked beets but hadn‚Äôt drained them when I cam across this recipe so I used the water that I‚Äôd cooked the beets in and added water to make about 7 cups. I peeled and shredded the beets (might've been about 2 cups worth) to add later. I peeled the sausage and chopped it to fry it in the pan. Cooked the onions separately the n added the tomato paste/water combination. I didn‚Äôt drain my diced tomatoes but that‚Äôs because I can my own with tomato juice and didn‚Äôt want to waste that good juice. I added chopped potatoes and shredded carrots to cook and when they were almost cooked I added the already cooked shredded beets and the cabbage. I didn‚Äôt have a head of cabbage so I used about 1/2 bag of shredded coleslaw mix. I didn‚Äôt add sugar but mostly because I overlooked it and I‚Äôm not sure it was needed. Each to their own I suppose. The only ingredient I thought was missing was fresh dill and because I had just bought a bag of super fresh wonderful smelling dill I chopped about a handful of dill. This will be one of my favourite soups ever. It looks so pretty when the sour cream is mixed in. UPDATE: I had a bowlful frozen and just tried it. Put this under the Freezes Beautifully column.
Love this recipe! Delicious and easy to follow. Thanks!
delicious. And better the second day. I left all the skins on and it tasted great. salt to taste - needed lots of salt! A+ We got four nights worth of dinner from this recipe for the two of us
Very good recipe, my whole family enjoyed it. Will definitely make it again!
Didn't have cabbage so used bok choy instead. Also recipe is really only good if large amount of sour cream added per serving. It's fine.

I've recently got engaged to a Latvian and he requested for his birthday that I make him Borscht. 

This was my first time making it. I prepped all of the shredded, peeled, and chopped items first. I used sweet pork sausage. I got a tip from his mom, which is to pan fry the shredded beets using the left over sausage grease. I cooked the beets for about 8 mins before tossing it in the pot.

My future husband's words: "Babe, this is some of the best borscht I've had."

Fantastic! Very satisfying and good looking presentation. Very good the next day; everything changes to a uniform red. Freezes well. 
I used mild Italian sausage and it was excellent. A Russian friend said his mother added paprika or red pepper in the winter or if they were sick. 
Made it once with turkey sausage. It was very bland. Even adding 1/2 lb of Ialian. Sausage didn't help it. Just don't use turkey or chicken if you want flavor.
Made it, loved it, made it again. This is a great recipe for borscht. My wife is Ukrainian, we would know!
Definitely will make again. Changes made no garlic and instead of plain pork slice up hot italian sausages
Phenomenal! Quite authentic and closely resembled the Borscht I had in Russia.
Best borscht recipe I‚Äôve tried! I didn‚Äôt use the sausage but it turned out great. The color is an absolutely wonderful deep red.
I actually canned the vegetables without the sausage. When we were ready to eat it, we used kielbasa, cooked that, and had the vegetables over the keilbasa.

The pork sausage is a delicious twist on the traditional beef. Did not add sugar, squeezed a little lime into each bowl instead. Had to cook the soup about 40 minutes longer for the potatoes and cabbage to be tender

I made this. It was definitely not like my grandmothers. I did not like everything shredded, it was more like a stew than a soup because of the tomato paste. It tasted too much like tomatoes. I made it again without the paste, and shredded only the beets to bring out the color and left the paste out. I liked it much better. I also made it from homemade chicken stock, and added a Tb or 2 of chicken soup base.

my girlfriend is from Ukraine, we use no sausage only chicken breast, potatoes, carrots, beets;nor tomato sauce, only ketchup the size of a silver dollar. fry all the onions until they are transparent, then add. Fry the beets then add. add carrots and potatoes, chicken cubed, and chicken broth. You may need to add more chicken broth;then the ketchup. i'll double check the recipe i wrote it down, but its very simple, and its delicious. frying the beets gives them a beautiful shine and adds flavor. very simple Yep that's it. Everyone makes it different.
my first time to make Borscht . Love it!!! A very tasty dish to serve on a cold ,rainy day or any day!
Great recipe!! But I believe it is meant to say dill not parsley. ;)

I substituted for a lot of things simply because I didn't have them. I only used one carrot, not three. Four beets, not three. Two tablespoons of heavy cream when it called for none (highly recommended for extra body/flavor). I added A LOT more sugar than what it called for until it tasted right. Didn't have any parsley so I used a bit of dried basil and FRESH DILL (super good). And I didn't have any quality pork sausage so I fried bacon and crumbled it over the top along with the sour cream as a garnish at the end. I would actually recommend all these changes because the soup turned out to be fantastic. However, in the future, I'd probably increase the carrots a bit and only use 3 beets :)
Only had one carrot and I used red cabbage. Yum!
Never had Borscht before. Reminds me a lot of tomato soup. Good and very filling!
An absolute family favorite! I add a bunch of fresh chopped Dill, and it's fabulous! Mmmm!
What a lovely soup. I will make this dish again. I didn't have any fresh dill or vinegar so I used pickle juice and balsamic vinaigrette.

Followed some of the other reviews and left off the sausage, used tomato sauce (what I had), red onion, 1/2 chicken 1/2 beef stock, dill and probably more sea salt than is good for me. Diced everything and left out the cabbage. I like it a lot, but will probably look for a beet recipe with beef.
I made it twice and added more meat. Bison. Ground church, and fresh grass fed ground sausage and more veggies made it even better. My husband preferred it more as Chunky Stew than a soup.
I didn't include the meat for those that might not want it. However I served kielbasi with the meal and cut mine up into my soup. What a treat. I also made pierogies to compliment the a perfect meal

I modified this recipe to make it vegan. Instead of pork sausage, I used Light Life Gimme Lean Veggie Sausage. I didn't have any cabbage or crushed tomatoes, so I just used the 6 oz. can of tomato paste and I added 1/4 of a large chopped rutabaga and added one extra cup of water to compensate for the crushed tomatoes. I also added 1 tbsp red wine vinegar ( I highly recommend doing this!). I garnished with Tofutti Sour Cream and some fresh chopped Italian parsley and served with rosemary potato bread. Yummy!
I‚Äôve made this recipe multiple times, and it‚Äôs become a family favorite. At various phases, each of my kids have declared Borscht their favorite food. I think it‚Äôs best without the meat.
Great with sausage
Pretty darn good. My first time eating this and highly recommend!
I love this recipe, but it comes out a little thick. I recommend using slightly less tomato paste.

My boyfriend made this and it was super delicious. Only modification was he used part spicy sausage. He likes things with a kick. If he hadn't, I'm sure it would be just as good. Paired well with a nice crusty bread.

My main question is... WHERE'S the DILL???

Other than that, I liked it. The sausage was a surprising new twist. I liked it. I omitted the tomatoes, but would like to try it with them, next time. I'm yet another person who has spent time eating Borscht in Russia. 

Lovely soup. Thanks!

Delicious! I am a vegetarian, so I did it without the meat, and it was really satisfying. But it was really annoying to prep. I wound up using a food processor for most of the ‚Äúshredded‚Äù parts. This certainly isn‚Äôt something I‚Äôll be making on a regular basis, but I can see making it on special occasions.

This is the best borscht I have ever tasted. The recipe was super easy to follow and the results were fantastic. I love the flavor that the sausage added. I did use vegetable broth instead of water to add a little richness to the soup. Also used fresh dill on top of sour cream for garnish, tastes much better than parsley. my family LOVED it!! highly recommend this recipe
AMAZING!!! I used 2lbs bone-in beef chuck to make beef stock instead of pork, and had to use 2 pots bc i don‚Äôt have one big enough. This is so so so good with the fresh dill and sour cream!

I first followed the recipe as written and was disappointed with it tasting bland, but then I added a lot of salt, sugar, garlic, pepper,and dill, and it tasted better. Then I tried it again a few hours later after the pot cooled off and it was amazing! Somehow just sitting all the flavors melded. I wish the recipe included an approximate amount of salt, since it's such a huge pot. I found I ended up adding at least 2 tablespoons before it wasn't bland, but I was doing it a half tsp at a time so it took a while.
Awful. Strong tasting raw garlic overpowered crunchy uncooked cabbage. Blech! Skip the gatlic and skip the cabbage and youve got a starting point. This batch gets flushed diwn the toilet.

I‚Äôve been eating and or making Borscht for 70 + years. My family came to the USA in 1900, so we know Borscht. This recipe has no dill in it. If there is no dill,...then it's not Borscht. You can change a lot of things in making Borscht but you must have Beets and Dill to even qualify as authentic borscht.
Also we normally made the stock the day before with browned and then very slowly cooked Ox Tail.

OK, I never worked with beets before and quite honestly, I did not know if I or my family would like them. But we found some at the farmers market and my daughter wanted to try.l So I found this recipe. Honestly, it looked a bit red but.. OMG it was so delicious I could not believe it. DId not have pork sausage so I made the vegetarian version.. SO delicious! Followed the recipe exactly. Well, I did not measure but... Thank you for a new family favorite!

I not only liked the soup, I had two guests that also liked the vegetarian style borscht. The only alterations I made was I used half of a medium sized sweet potato Instead of 3 potatoes because that‚Äôs what I had and I used half a can of tomato paste. I served it with a dollop of plain yogurt instead of sour cream and a hard garlic roll. I will make it again!!!

I used only 1/2 a package of sausage, well drained and rinsed with hot water. Instead of water I used chicken bone broth for more flavor. I used a decent amount of fresh dill-3tbs in the soup and more for on top. And I also added 3tbs of red wine vinegar (which I had noticed used on other borscht recipes).
I made this exactly as this recipe says and it turned out great! I'm wondering if some kind of herb would be good in it... some say dill? I might try that next time.
My family loves this recipe. The only thing i dont like is the pork sausage casing when cooking. You have to make sure it is all removed.

I made this soup last week, almost exactly as directed by the recipe (added a little less tomato and did add a little dill and vinegar). Served it for dinner, and the reaction was meh. Not enough taste. Put the rest away -- it makes a lot -- dreading eating the leftovers. BUT when it came out of the fridge a couple days later, it wasn't meh. It was yummy. This may just be one of those recipes that is so much better the next day.
Because I live with a vegan, I left out the meat. I added sour cream to my bowl rather than the pot and didn't miss the meat at all.
Delicious! I omitted the sugar but otherwise made it as written. The flavour is wonderful but I'm not sure I'm a fan of the shredded beets and carrots.
Made some minor tweaks but its a good base recipe

This is the first time I made Borscht. We had it when we were in Russia and Poland. This recipe is good and I made a vegan version of it using vegan sausage. I don't think it needs the meat. It would be so clean without the meat. It really tastes good but I think it would taste better without the sausage. I would make this again. It does not look like the picture because the beets are shredded. I will also add less veggies to make it more like a soup and less like a stew! My beets were huge! Thank you so much!

This will do but this is not a traditional borsht, it is a family recipe 
normally you would :
1) add beans; soak large beans for a day and then add it to boiled ribs
2) cook it with ribs for meat (boil them for half an hour before all other ingredients are added)
3) on skillet add long slices of beets as well-> it brings the taste
4) add 2-3 bay leaves 15 min before borsht is done. 

To make it vegetarian: 
instead of meat add mushrooms or do not add anything, usually that what people do for fasting, it is tasty in veg option as well.
Serve it with:
Take a piece of bread and brown it from 2 sides in olive oil, as soon as it cools down a bit, grind a clove of garlic on it; add minced dill on a top of soup bowl

The only reason to cook the Pork is for the flavour of the frond (meat caramelized) why not do it in the heavy bottomed soup pot? The instructions above throw it away by leaving it in the pan? Seasoned meat, liberally salted and peppered, gives more flavour. De glaze the soup pot with a little red wine, beer or any spirits, or meat or vegetable stock, or diced onion, garlic (celery, fennel bulb, bell pepper, shredded horse or other radish) tomato paste (for Umami) and any of the above liquids. Cook for a few minutes till softened then add your liquid (water or stock).
Parboiling or blanching the cabbage will reduce the flatulent gaseousness of this veg. Don't peel the beets if you're going to shred them especially, you throw away the flavor, color and all the best food value. All the Ukrainians I've known, do not use tomatoes they use a splash of vinegar. The acidity of the tomatoes should hold the rich color of the beets, you can also add some vinegar here to set color and give the soup a little kick. I add a splash of dill pickle juice. Dill fiends will also lace the soup with copious amounts of Dill weed when adding the tomatoes or the last 10-20 minutes of cooking. IMHO

The things I changed were to substitute cross cut beef shortribs for the sausage, parsnips for potatoes, and I omitted the dairy garnish and the sugar. (I made it Paleo-style.) I also chopped the beets into cubes rather than grating them, since I didn't feel like cleaning up the hot pink kitchen crime scene. As I've never had Borscht before, I cannot comment on authenticity, but this recipe makes a subtle-tasting, delicious, velvety-rich stew. The jewel-toned red color adds a visual that elevates the dish. It's a new favorite. I'll definitely make this again when I have sausage on hand.
Not very hard. I used a food processor to shred and used beef instead of pork. Really good.

I've just started cooking again now that I am retired and have the time. I try to follow recipes exactly, since I feel like an absolute beginner again. I made a couple small mistakes with this one: did not put in the potatoes and cabbage and diced tomatoes when I was supposed to. In spite of that, it was absolutely delicious! Only problem is I now have a huge pot of borscht despite cutting the recipe in half!

I will definitely make this soup again, though I changed a few things. I left out the tomato paste, as someone else suggested, and I garnished it with dill rather than parsley. I think I would like to try it with no meat and pureeing the final product., for a chilled summer soup.
I don't like beets and this was a very good, very flavorful dish. The sour cream added a good taste, just don't *stir* it into the dish.
Omitted the pork sausage, turned out delicious! I didn't even feel like it needed any sugar added at the end, very sweet and delicious

Really balanced flavor! Not overpowering beetiness as some are. A really good way to introduce someone to this style of soup. I used very mild pork sausage. A very good and nutritious soup. Fresh dill would be a nice addition

This was delicious!! It was my first time having Borscht and it won't be my last! I boiled my beets for 1 hour and then pealed and shredded them. I used 4 beets for more beet flavor as others felt like the beer flavor was weak. I left out the tomatoes past and tomatoes as I was told from a Ukrainian, she had never had tomatoes in hers. I left out the sugar as was recommended by many and I added Apple cider vinegar 1 TBSP and a handful of chopped fresh dill at the end. I served this with crusty garlic bread...so good!!

This is a excellent Borscht soup! After reading many of the reviews I chose to leave out the meat and boil the washed beets in the water used for the soup (to easily remove the skin and grate). Taste is good the first day, it's amazing the second day after the flavors marry and get happy!

I'd never had borscht before, but this looked so easy, I decided to give it a try. Turns out I like borscht, which is good, because this recipe made about two week's worth of lunches. Not sure how "authentic" it is, but it certainly is delicious.
